awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type II - University of Delaware I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project from the University of Delaware that extends their I-Corps Site funding for scale up to their next phase of support for innovation and entrepreneurship. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. 

The University of Delaware's (UD's) I-Corps Site, established in 2014, resulted in "fostering a spirit of innovation and entrepreneurship" as one of the University's five strategic goals; instutionalizing  Lean Launchpad methods as the cornerstone for academic offerings in entrepreneurship; increased enrollments in entrepreneurship courses; and, resources for supporting entrepreneurship activities  increased by more than 500%, enabling the launch of additional support programs like a venture mentoring service based on MIT's VMS model. Advancing into the next stage, they will create a seamless pathway for participants to engage in commercialization, engage in continuous improvement of the curriculum, advance additional teams to the I-Corps National Program and directly to startups, and offer follow-on services as team projects mature and have potential to attract investors. The Site will also continue to engage in inclusiveness activities to attract underrepresented participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project represented a follow on to the University of Delaware's (UD's) 2014 proposal entitled, "I-Corps Site as an Ecosystem Catalyst". In eight years post-award, the impacts and outcomes associated with the UD I-Corps Site have exceeded the high expectations reflected in this title. Specific impacts include: (1) contributing to the establishment of "fostering a spirit of innovation and entrepreneurship" as one of the University's five strategic goals, (2) institutionalizing Lean Launchpad methods as the cornerstone for academic offerings in entrepreneurship, (3) institutionalizing Lean Launchpad methods as a key element of the UD Tech Transfer Office's commercialization process, (4) institutionalizing the UD I-Corps Site program as the lynchpin for the innovative Blue Hen Proof of Concept Program, and (5) facilitating the expansion of entrepreneurship offerings, such as a new UD Launch Fund, which will offer preseed equity funding to startups leveraging university IP as well as those founded by students, recent alumni and faculty.

In terms of direct UD I-Corps Site outcomes: (1) twenty-six cohorts completed the program, (2) each of the 214 teams trained through the Site has been granted an award of up to $3,000 to support customer discovery activities, (3) 27 UD-I-Corps-Site affiliated teams have been accepted to the national NSF I-Corps Teams program, providing them with an additional $50,000 and a 7-week training bootcamp, and (4) more than 30 UD I-Corps Site teams have received follow on funding, primarily via SBIR/STTR, totaling more than $43M.

At the conclusion of the award period, UD's I-Corps Site program consisted of five, three-hour training sessions, which had been continuously refined to guide teams in seeking to conduct an initial assessment of commercialization potential through value proposition design and customer discovery research. These sessions were supplemented by weekly mentoring sessions and access to startup advising & other supportive resources available through UD's Horn Entrepreneurship. In total, 100% of participants who provided feedback on the UD/Horn I-Corps Site program rated it as "meeting" or "exceeding" their expectations and 91% rated it as "very" or "extremely" valuable. In addition, 99% of participants rated the quality of instruction and mentorship as "good" or better. 

Horn Entrepreneurship has successfully leveraged UD's I-Corps Site program to realize broader impacts. For example, the Site program served as the basis for a 2017 pilot program entitled, "Delaware Startup Launchpad", which offered 3 cohorts of training sessions and the opportunity to compete for funding awards totaling $5,000 to twenty-two community-based startups. In addition, UD/Horn was awarded an I-Corps supplement, which facilitated a close partnership with Delaware State University (DSU), an HBCU, providing new training opportunities for STEM faculty and students who are underrepresented minorities (URMs). The supplement also enabled UD/Horn to provide support to URM teams from four neighboring Universities - Rowan, Drexel, Temple, and Thomas Jefferson - while paving the way for UD's involvement with the new Northeast I-Corps Hub led by Princeton University. 

In summary, the UD/Horn I-Corps Site has served as an effective catalyst for the development of the entrepreneurship ecosystem.

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2023
Modified by: Dan Freeman
